caption: Table 1: Definitions of energy functions (in reduced units) used for each of the five chemical properties investigated in this work. Here y refers to the generated molecule.
description: This table lists the five chemical properties used in the paper's experiments and defines the corresponding energy functions used in the ERA algorithm.  The energy functions are expressed in reduced units, and 'y' represents the generated molecule.  The table provides a concise mapping between property names and their mathematical representation within the ERA framework.
section: C Details for molecular generator experiments

caption: Table 2: Property-specific energy values (in reduced units) used to treat chemically invalid sequences.
description: This table lists the energy values used for handling invalid chemical sequences during the experiments.  These energy values are in reduced units and are specific to the five chemical properties investigated in the study: Tanimoto similarity, QED, Wildman-Crippen LogP, Molar refractivity, and Ring count.  High energy values penalize invalid sequences.

caption: Table 3: Percentage of generated sequences that were chemically valid for samples from unprompted molecular generator after alignment. (See Fig. 2, Section 4.1.1).
description: This table shows the percentage of chemically valid molecules generated by the unprompted molecular generator model after applying the energy rank alignment algorithm for different properties (Molar Refractivity, Ring Count, LogP, QED) and hyperparameter settings (β, μ, σ, γ).  The "Unaligned" row shows the baseline chemical validity before applying the algorithm. The table provides insight into the algorithm's effect on the validity of generated molecules. Lower chemical validity percentages may indicate that the alignment process is causing the generation of more chemically invalid molecules.

caption: Table 3: Percentage of generated sequences that were chemically valid for samples from unprompted molecular generator after alignment. (See Fig. 2, Section 4.1.1).
description: This table shows the percentage of chemically valid molecules generated by the unprompted molecular generator model after alignment for different properties (Molar Refractivity, Ring Count, LogP, QED) and hyperparameter settings (beta, mu, sigma, gamma).  The 'Unaligned' row shows the baseline chemical validity before any alignment.  The lower chemical validity percentages after alignment for some settings indicates that the alignment process sometimes results in the generation of chemically invalid molecules. The figure reference (Fig 2) and section reference (Section 4.1.1) help to locate more context.

caption: Table 5: Percentage of generated sequences that were chemically valid for samples from prompted molecular generator after multi-property alignment. (See Fig. 4, Section 4.1.2).
description: This table shows the percentage of chemically valid molecules generated by a prompted molecular generator after multi-property alignment using different hyperparameter settings.  The hyperparameters control the balance between targeting multiple properties (Tanimoto similarity, LogP, QED) during the alignment process. The unaligned model serves as a baseline for comparison.  The results indicate that although there is a drop in chemical validity, a significant number of the samples remain chemically valid.

caption: Table 3: Percentage of generated sequences that were chemically valid for samples from unprompted molecular generator after alignment. (See Fig. 2, Section 4.1.1).
description: This table shows the percentage of chemically valid molecules generated by the unprompted molecular generator model after applying the energy rank alignment algorithm for different properties and hyperparameter settings.  The "unaligned" row represents the percentage of valid molecules generated by the model before alignment. The other rows show the results after alignment for different target properties (Molar Refractivity, Ring Count, LogP, and QED), with different hyperparameter settings (β and μ for some properties). The table helps to demonstrate the algorithm's robustness and the trade-off between achieving desired properties and maintaining chemical validity.

caption: Table 3: Percentage of generated sequences that were chemically valid for samples from unprompted molecular generator after alignment. (See Fig. 2, Section 4.1.1).
description: This table presents the percentage of chemically valid molecules generated by an unprompted molecular generator model before and after alignment for various properties.  The hyperparameters used in the ERA algorithm (beta, mu, sigma, gamma) during the alignment process are listed, showing different settings for each property.  The chemical validity of the generated molecules is reported, highlighting the impact of ERA on both property alignment and chemical validity.  This table supports the discussion in section 4.1.1 regarding the effects of ERA on unprompted molecular generation.
